page.title: List of accidents and incidents involving airliners in the United States

rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. Also fails [[WP:NFLISTS]]
rev.diff:
Line 26: Line 26:
==Arkansas==<!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED -->
==Arkansas==<!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED -->
â
[[File:AmericanA1420.jpg|left|thumb|[[American Airlines Flight 1420]] after overrunning the runway on June 1, 1999.]]
 
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 1420]]''' overran the runway while attempting to land at [[Little Rock National Airport]] on June 1, 1999. The pilots decided to land though heavy winds and [[wind shear]] exceeded the safety limits for the aircraft, and in their rush to land they made a number of critical errors that led to the flight's crash. The captain and ten passengers were killed on impact.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2001). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2001/AAR0102.htm "Aircraft Accident Report: Runway Overrun During Landing; American Airlines Flight 1420; McDonnell Douglas MD-82, N215AA; Little Rock, Arkansas; 1 June 1999".] Retrieved December 23, 2005.</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 1420]]''' overran the runway while attempting to land at [[Little Rock National Airport]] on June 1, 1999. The pilots decided to land though heavy winds and [[wind shear]] exceeded the safety limits for the aircraft, and in their rush to land they made a number of critical errors that led to the flight's crash. The captain and ten passengers were killed on impact.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2001). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2001/AAR0102.htm "Aircraft Accident Report: Runway Overrun During Landing; American Airlines Flight 1420; McDonnell Douglas MD-82, N215AA; Little Rock, Arkansas; 1 June 1999".] Retrieved December 23, 2005.</ref>
Line 132: Line 131:
==Colorado==
==Colorado==
â
[[File:Continental 1404.jpg|right|thumb|[[Continental Airlines Flight 1404]] crashed during takeoff from [[Denver International Airport]] on December 20, 2008]]
 
* A chartered Avjet [[Gulfstream III]] [[business jet]] '''[[2001 Avjet Aspen crash|crashed]]''' into terrain while on instrument approach to [[Aspen-Pitkin County Airport]], [[Aspen, Colorado]], killing all 18 on board. <ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2002). [http://www.ntsb.gov/Publictn/2002/AAB0203.pdf Aircraft Accident Brief: Avject Corporation; Gulfstream III, N303GA; Aspen, Colorado; March 29, 2001]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* A chartered Avjet [[Gulfstream III]] [[business jet]] '''[[2001 Avjet Aspen crash|crashed]]''' into terrain while on instrument approach to [[Aspen-Pitkin County Airport]], [[Aspen, Colorado]], killing all 18 on board. <ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2002). [http://www.ntsb.gov/Publictn/2002/AAB0203.pdf Aircraft Accident Brief: Avject Corporation; Gulfstream III, N303GA; Aspen, Colorado; March 29, 2001]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>

Line 276: Line 273:
==Iowa==
==Iowa==
â
[[File:UA232postcrash.jpg|right|thumb|The remains of the fuselage of [[United Airlines Flight 232]] after its crash-landing on July 19, 1989.]]
 
* A [[Beechcraft Bonanza]] crashed near [[Clear Lake, Iowa]] on February 3, 1959, '''[[The Day the Music Died|killing three American rock 'n' roll musicians]]''': [[Buddy Holly]], [[Ritchie Valens]], and [[The Big Bopper|J. P. "The Big Bopper" Richardson]].
* A [[Beechcraft Bonanza]] crashed near [[Clear Lake, Iowa]] on February 3, 1959, '''[[The Day the Music Died|killing three American rock 'n' roll musicians]]''': [[Buddy Holly]], [[Ritchie Valens]], and [[The Big Bopper|J. P. "The Big Bopper" Richardson]].
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 232]]''' - Crash-landed at [[Sioux Gateway Airport]] in [[Sioux City]] after explosion of the No. 2 engine destroyed all three hydraulic systems
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 232]]''' - Crash-landed at [[Sioux Gateway Airport]] in [[Sioux City]] after explosion of the No. 2 engine destroyed all three hydraulic systems
Line 403: Line 399:
==New Hampshire==
==New Hampshire==
â
[[File:Gb-015.jpg|right|thumb|Wreckage of [[Northeast Airlines Flight 946]].]]
 
*'''[[Northeast Airlines Flight 946]]''' crashed near [[Etna, New Hampshire]] on October 25, 1968, killing 32 passengers and crew. The [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] determined that the plane was flying {{convert|600|ft}} below its required altitude, though the reason for this is unknown. The NTSB report suggests that the pilots misjudged their altitude position during approach due to a lack of [[navigational aid]]s on the aircraft and near the airport. <ref>National Transportation Safety Board. (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-07.pdf Aircraft accident report : Northeast Airlines, Inc., Fairchild Hiller FH-227C, N380NE, near Hanover, New Hampshire, October 25, 1968]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
*'''[[Northeast Airlines Flight 946]]''' crashed near [[Etna, New Hampshire]] on October 25, 1968, killing 32 passengers and crew. The [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] determined that the plane was flying {{convert|600|ft}} below its required altitude, though the reason for this is unknown. The NTSB report suggests that the pilots misjudged their altitude position during approach due to a lack of [[navigational aid]]s on the aircraft and near the airport. <ref>National Transportation Safety Board. (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-07.pdf Aircraft accident report : Northeast Airlines, Inc., Fairchild Hiller FH-227C, N380NE, near Hanover, New Hampshire, October 25, 1968]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
